Estimating the exact number of weasels living in high-risk regions can be challenging as they are usually small and hard to detect. However, there are ongoing efforts to monitor their populations and estimate their numbers.

The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species provides some information on the population size and trend of various weasel species worldwide. For instance, the European Mink (Mustela lutreola) is estimated to have a population of fewer than 500 mature individuals, while the Japanese Weasel (Mustela itatsi) has a population of about 14,000 mature individuals.

In a particular high-risk region, studies can be conducted using various methods such as camera traps, track counts, DNA analysis, and community surveys, to estimate the population of weasels. These studies can help identify the status of the population and determine the appropriate conservation measures to implement.

It's essential to gather more information about the population of weasels in high-risk regions to understand the severity of the situation and take appropriate measures to prevent their extinction.
